titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Hans W. Loewald Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Bella Z. Berson

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 9, 2019 at 09:10

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers include correspondence, writings, and notes, which document Hans Loewald's influence in the fields of psychiatry and psychoanalysis as a writer, teacher, and clinician.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Hans W. Loewald Papers (MS 1721). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Dr. Hans L. Holocaust testimony (HVT-205) [videotape]. Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimony, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Hans W. Loewald was born in 1906 in the Alsatian town of Colmar. After serving a medical internship in Berlin, Loewald left his native Germany. He received his medical degree from the University of Rome in 1934 and practiced psychiatry in Padua until 1939, after which he moved to the United States. There, he was an assistant professor in psychiatry at the University of Maryland Medical School and, from 1955 through 1974, was an active member of the Yale University School of Medicine faculty in psychiatry. He affiliated with the Western New England Institute for Psychoanalysis in 1955 and served as its president. Loewald died on January 9, 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers include correspondence, writings, and notes, which document Hans Loewald's influence in the fields of psychiatry and psychoanalysis as a writer, teacher, and clinician.

controlaccess.subject: Psychiatry
Psychoanalysis
controlaccess.corpname: Western New England Institute for Psychoanalysis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers are composed primarily of correspondence and writings, which document Hans Loewald's career in psychiatry. The papers do not include personal materials documenting his early training or his decision to emigrate and, except for a few photographs, date largely from his time in the United States. The correspondence is arranged alphabetically, while writings with known dates are chronologically arranged. Undated writings follow, arranged alphabetically by title. For both published or unpublished writings, the files may include notes, drafts, and associated correspondence.
